{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{History of Lebanon}}
Starting in 2004, a series of '''bombings and assassinations''' struck [[Lebanon]], most of them in and around the capital, [[Beirut]]. This wave of bombings began with the assassination attempt on Marwan Hamadeh, then became more intense with the assassination of former Prime Minister [[Rafiq Hariri]] on February 14, 2005, which touched off the [[Cedar Revolution]] and the withdrawal of [[Syrian army|Syrian troops]]. After the massive protests following Hariri's killing, several more bombings hit Lebanon.
These bombings and assassinations came after September 2004, when the Lebanese Parliament was pressured by Syria to extend the term of pro-Syrian President Emile Lahoud through a constitutional amendment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3626280.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Lebanon extends president's term|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> The MPs, journalists, and activists that opposed this term extension were subject to slander, harassment and, in many cases, assassination attempts. Since 2013 most of the bombings were not related to the Cedar Revolution but rather a spillover of the Syrian civil war.
This list is limited to bombings and assassinations; it does not include other form of attacks. It is presented in chronological order. All entries must be cited or have their own article.
==2004==
* Marwan Hamadeh assassination attempt (October 1){{snd}}A [[car bomb]] exploded next to the motorcade carrying [[Druze in Lebanon|Druze]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Marwan Hamadeh]]. Hamadeh was injured, but survived; his driver was killed. Hamadeh was a critic of Syria and a member of the opposition to President [[Émile Lahoud]].<ref name="dailystar.com.lb">http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2012/Oct-20/192095-timeline-of-explosions-and-targeted-assassinations-from-2004-to-2012.ashx</ref>
==2005==
[[Image:Guarding Ground Zero.jpg|thumb|Ministry of the Interior soldier guarding the site of the attack that killed former Prime Minister Hariri]] * Rafiq Hariri assassination (February 14){{snd}}A massive explosion killed former Lebanese [[Prime Minister]] [[Rafiq Hariri]] in [[Beirut]], near the St. George Hotel. The former Minister of the Economy, [[Bassel Fleihan]], was also among the 22 killed. About 220 others were wounded. A group calling itself "Al Nusra and Jihad in greater Syria" claimed responsibility for the blast.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jun/22/worlddispatch.syria|title=Beirut murder mystery|author=Brian Whitaker|work=the Guardian|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> According to the [[United Nations|UN]] report,<ref name="Mehlis">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/dh/docs/mehlisreport|title=REPORT|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> released October 20, the blast was the result of a [[truck bomb]]. Security video had captured a white truck driving near Hariri's convoy which investigators determined was carrying an estimated 1,000 kg of explosives. Since Hariri's convoy had jamming devices meant to block [[remote control]] signals, the attack was carried out using a [[suicide bomber]]. The report cited a witness who said the bomber was an [[Iraq]]i who was led to believe his target was Iraqi Prime Minister [[Iyad Allawi]], who had been in Beirut just days before. The report concluded that top Syrian and Lebanese officials planned the assassination beginning in mid-2004. *New Jdeideh bombing (March 19){{snd}}A car bomb exploded in the [[New Jdeideh]] suburb of Beirut. The blast happened in a mixed commercial-residential area and wounded 11 people. Reports said that the driver had tried to park in front of a [[Bingo (US)|bingo]] hall and was turned away, so he instead parked next to an apartment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/mar/19/syria.lebanon|title=Car bomb rocks Beirut|work=the Guardian|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Kaslik bombing (March 23){{snd}}A bomb left in a leather bag exploded at the back entrance of the Kaslik shopping center in Jounieh. Two Indian and one Pakistani [[janitor]] were killed, and two Sri Lankans and two Lebanese injured. The roof of the mall collapsed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/story/A3CC2B61CD4D7E84C2256FCD00250C7B?OpenDocument|title=Naharnet — Lebanon's leading news destination|work=Naharnet|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Sad el-Bouchrieh bombing (March 26){{snd}}A car bomb parked between two factories exploded in the Sad el-Bouchrieh area of Beirut, wounding 6 people. It caused a blaze which destroyed several workshops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4385265.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Bomb hits Beirut's Christian area|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Broummana bombing (April 1){{snd}}A bomb ripped through the Rizk plaza in the [[Broummana]] resort village, {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of Beirut. 12 people were injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A19372-2005Apr1.html|title=Bomb Damages Christian Town Near Beirut|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> [[Image:Jounieh bomb aftermath.jpg|thumb|Jounieh bomb aftermath]] *Jounieh bombing (May 7){{snd}}A car bomb exploded between the Christian Sawt al Mahaba [[radio station]] and the Mar Yuhanna [[Church (building)|Church]] in [[Jounieh]]. The radio station was destroyed and the church suffered major damage. 22 people were wounded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/0505/05050706AFP.asp|title=Lebanonwire.com - Lebanon police say no dead after all in Jounieh blast|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129052235/http://www.lebanonwire.com/0505/05050706AFP.asp|archivedate=29 November 2014|df=}}</ref> *Samir Kassir assassination (June 2){{snd}}Anti-Syrian journalist [[Samir Kassir]] was assassinated when a bomb detonated in his car outside his home in Beirut's Ashrafiyeh district, a largely Christian residential area. Kassir was a front-page columnist for the ''[[al-Nahar]]'' newspaper, where he wrote columns criticizing the pro-Syrian government.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2005/Jun-02/4583-journalist-samir-kassir-assassinated-in-beirut-blast.ashx</ref> *George Hawi assassination (June 21){{snd}}Former [[Lebanese Communist Party]] leader [[George Hawi]], a critic of Syria, died when his car exploded as he was driving through Beirut's Wata Musaitbi district.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/22/world/middleeast/car-bomb-kills-another-antisyria-politician-in-beirut.html</ref> *Elias Murr assassination attempt (July 12){{snd}}A car bomb wounded the outgoing Lebanese defense minister, [[Elias Murr]], as his motorcade drove through Beirut's Christian suburb of Antelias. 2 people were killed and 12 others injured. This attack was unique in the series of bombings in that Murr was considered a pro-Syrian figure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/meast/07/12/beirut.bomb/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007100211/http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/meast/07/12/beirut.bomb/index.html |archivedate=2008-10-07 |df= }}</ref> *Monot bombing (July 22){{snd}}A bomb exploded in a car parked in front of a restaurant on Monot Street in Beirut, wounding 12 people. The bomb was estimated to be {{convert|50|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/meast/07/22/lebanon.explosion/index.html|title=CNN.com - Explosion hits Beirut - Jul 22, 2005|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Zalka bombing (August 22){{snd}}In the mostly Christian neighborhood of [[Zalka]] a bomb placed between a shopping center and a hotel damaged shops and windows, wounding 8 people. It consisted of {{convert|20|to|30|kg|abbr=on}} of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] and was set on a [[timer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/0805/05082501IRWIN.asp|title=Lebanonwire.com - Lebanon traders take financial blow after bombing|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129052236/http://www.lebanonwire.com/0805/05082501IRWIN.asp|archivedate=29 November 2014|df=}}</ref> *Jeitawi bombing (September 17){{snd}}An explosion in the largely Christian area of Ashrafieh killed 1 person and injured 23 others. It was believed to have been caused by a car bomb; two cars were destroyed and buildings near the blast were severely damaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsgroups.derkeiler.com/Archive/Soc/soc.culture.lebanon/2005-09/msg00463.html|title=Powerful Bomb Rocks Ashrafiyeh's Jeitawi Neighborhood, 1 Dead, 25 Injured|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *May Chidiac assassination attempt (September 25){{snd}}Christian journalist and critic of Syria [[May Chidiac]] was seriously injured when a bomb exploded as she got into her car in Jounieh. She lost her left leg and arm. Chidiac was an [[news presenter|anchor]] on the [[Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation]].<ref name="dailystar.com.lb"/> *Gebran Tueni assassination (December 12){{snd}}A prominent anti-Syrian journalist and lawmaker, [[Gebran Tueni]], was killed by a car bomb. He had returned from [[France]] only a day earlier, where he had been staying for fear of assassination. His driver and a passerby were also killed when a car bomb exploded as his motorcade drove through [[Mkalles]], an industrial suburb of Beirut. 3 people were killed and another 30 wounded in the bombing, and at least 10 vehicles were destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=16905&Cr=middle&Cr1=leban|title=United Nations News Centre|date=12 December 2005|work=UN News Service Section|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> The December 28 ''[[An-Nahar|An Nahar]]'' reported that the group "The Strugglers for the Unity and Freedom in al Sham" had claimed responsibility for the bombing in a statement which said outgoing [[UNIIIC]] chairman [[Detlev Mehlis]] was lucky to escape death and threatened any new chairman with assassination if he too implicated [[Syria]].<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20051228/ap_on_re_mi_ea/lebanon;_ylt=An.v6OlZ1vUFABXmXy4kEqpvaA8F;_ylu=X3oDMTA5aHJvMDdwBHNlYwN5bmNhdA--</ref>
==2006==
*Mahmoud al Majzoub assassination (May 25){{snd}}A bomb killed Mahmoud al Majzoub, the leader of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, in Sidon, south of Lebanon.<ref>[[Mahmoud al-Majzoub]]</ref> *Pierre Amine Gemayel assassination (November 21){{snd}}Anti-Syrian Minister of Industry [[Pierre Amine Gemayel]], son of [[Kataeb]] leader [[Amin Gemayel]] and nephew of assassinated President [[Bashir Gemayyel]], was shot dead in Beirut.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6169606.stm</ref>
==2007==
*Bikfaya bombing (February 13){{snd}}A bomb on a bus near Bikfaya killed 3 people and wounded 21 others.<ref name="The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon">{{cite web|url=http://dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2012/Oct-20/192095-timeline-of-explosions-and-targeted-assassinations-from-2004-to-2012.ashx#axzz3AFnIuaXb|title=Timeline of explosions and targeted assassinations from 2004 to 2012|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *ABC bombing (May 20){{snd}}Explosives placed near the ABC mall in Achrafieh killed 1 civilian and wounded 18 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2007/May-22/46074-achrafieh-bomb-arrived-in-unregistered-vehicle.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Achrafieh bomb 'arrived in unregistered vehicle'|author=Iman Azzi|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Verdun bombing (May 21){{snd}}An explosion in the affluent Beirut district of Verdun injured 10 people including 2 children.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://old.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/story/7650B480057C7524C22572E3001BCCEF?OpenDocument |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813190743/http://old.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/story/7650B480057C7524C22572E3001BCCEF?OpenDocument |archivedate=2014-08-13 |df= }}</ref> *Aley bombing (May 23){{snd}}An explosion in the town of Aley wounded 5 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2007/05/24/druze-lebanese-point-finger-at-syria?videoId=54187|title=Druze Lebanese point finger at Syria|work=Reuters|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Walid Eido assassination (June 13){{snd}}[[Walid Eido]], an anti-Syrian MP, was killed by a car bomb in Beirut along with 8 others, including his eldest son Khaled Eido.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jun/14/syria.lebanon</ref> *Antoine Ghanem assassination (September 19){{snd}}Anti-Syrian Lebanese MP [[Antoine Ghanem]] and four others were killed in a car bomb attack in a Christian suburb of Beirut. *Francois Elias Hajj assassination (December 12){{snd}}Brigadier General [[François al-Hajj]], from the village of Rmaich, was among 4 killed in a car bomb attack in Baabda.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/13/world/middleeast/13lebanon.html?_r=0</ref>
==2008==
*US diplomat bombing (January 15){{snd}}A bomb targeted against a US diplomatic vehicle killed 4 Lebanese civilians and wounded 16 others.<ref name="The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon"/> *Wissam Eid assassination (January 25){{snd}}Capt. Wissam Eid, Lebanese Internal Security Forces senior terrorism investigator, was assassinated. At the time of the attack, Eid was also the top Lebanese investigator into the assassination of Prime Minister Rafiq Hariri.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jan-27/245373-rally-pays-tribute-to-isfs-wissam-eid.ashx</ref> *Tripoli bus bombing (August 13){{snd}}A bomb targeting a civilian bus in Tripoli killed 16 people, including 7 Lebanese soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSLD6575120080813|title=Lebanon bomb kills 16, including 7 soldiers|work=Reuters|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Saleh Aridi assassination (September 10){{snd}}[[Saleh Aridi]], a pro-Syrian [[Druze in Lebanon|Druze]] politician of the [[Lebanese Democratic Party]], was killed by a car bomb.<ref>http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24329378-2703,00.html</ref> *Tripoli car bomb (September 29){{snd}}A car bomb destroyed a bus in Tripoli, killing 5 soldiers and injuring 35 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/oman/3101351/Lebanon-Bus-bomb-kills-soldiers-in-Tripoli.html|title=Lebanon: Bus bomb kills soldiers in Tripoli|author=Andrew Wander in Beirut|date=29 September 2008|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref>
==2012==
*Wissam al Hassan assassination (October 19){{snd}}Head of the intelligence branch of the Internal Security Forces (ISF) Maj. Gen. [[Wissam al-Hassan]] was killed by a massive car bomb in Achrafieh. 128 were injured and 8 others died.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Local-News/2012/Oct-19/192029-sound-of-large-explosion-in-ashrafieh-beirut.ashx</ref>
==2013==
*Roueiss bombing (August 15){{snd}}An attack on the Roueiss neighborhood in south Beirut killed 27 people and injured over 300. The attack was believed to have been carried out through a car bomb. Similar to the Beir el-Abed bombing, this attack targeted a Hizbollah stronghold.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2013/Aug-15/227505-explosion-in-southern-suburb-of-beirut-witnesses.ashx</ref> *Tripoli dual bombings (August 23){{snd}}Bombs hit two mosques killing at least 42 people and wounding hundreds. The first explosion hit the Taqwa mosque, and killed at least 14 people there. Further deaths were reported from a second blast a few minutes later outside the al-Salam mosque, which the Interior Ministry said was hit by a car laden with 100 kg (220 lbs) of explosives.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2013/Aug-23/228408-explosion-heard-in-north-lebanon.ashx</ref> *Beir Hassan bombing (November 19){{snd}}A large explosion near an Iranian cultural center in the southern suburbs of Beirut killed at least 22 people and injured 146 others in a double bomb attack. The explosion appeared to have been caused by a car bomb and a motorcycle laden with explosives.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2013/Nov-20/238399-terror-attack-puts-lebanon-on-brink.ashx</ref> *Hassan Lakkis assassination (December 3){{snd}}A senior Hezbollah commander named [[Hassan Lakkis]] was assassinated by two gunmen in Beirut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jun-30/262109-israeli-report-offers-details-of-hezbollahs-lakkis-assassination.ashx|title=Report exposes details of Lakkis assassination|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Mohamad Chatah assassination (December 27){{snd}}Former-minister [[Mohamad Chatah]], member of the Future Movement, and 5 others were killed by a car bomb that targeted Chatah's vehicle. Approximately 70 people were wounded in the attack.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2013/Dec-27/242407-former-minister-killed-in-beirut-car-bomb.ashx</ref>
==2014==
*Haret Hreik bombing (January 2){{snd}}Explosives were detonated in front of the political office of Hizbollah, killing 4 and injuring 77 others. Several buildings were damaged and flames engulfed vehicles parked on Al-Arid Street, where the explosives-rigged vehicle had been parked.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jan-02/242913-huge-explosion-rocks-beiruts-southern-suburbs.ashx</ref> *1st Hermel bombing (January 16){{snd}}A suspected suicide car-bombing killed 5 people and wounded 42 others in a bustling neighborhood in the northeastern town of Hermel.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jan-16/244215-car-bomb-in-lebanons-hermel-kills-one-wounds-more.ashx</ref> *2nd Hermel bombing (February 1){{snd}}Another terrorist explosion targeted Hermel, killing 4 and injuring 23 civilians in an attack that was claimed by an Al-Qaeda-linked group. The suicide bomber drove a Grand Cherokee Jeep up to a petrol station in the Zahraa area of the city where he then detonated a car bomb.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Feb-01/246080-sound-of-explosion-in-lebanons-hermel-al-manar.ashx#axzz2wDsxjKLW|title=Suicide car bomb kills at least four in Lebanon’s Hermel|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Van bombing (February 3){{snd}}A suicide bombing injured 2 people south of Beirut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Feb-03/246237-explosion-in-town-south-of-beirut.ashx#axzz3DrnM6eIf|title=Suicide bomber blows self up on bus south of Beirut|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Iranian cultural center bombings (February 19){{snd}}Two suicide bombings killed 8 people and wounded 128 others near the Iranian cultural center in Beirut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Feb-19/247793-twin-suicide-car-bombings-kill-five.ashx#axzz3Awt3Dao3|title=Twin suicide car bombings kill eight in Beirut|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *3rd Hermel bombing (February 22){{snd}}A suicide car bombing targeting an army post in Hermel killed 3 people including 2 soldiers and wounded 17 others. The Lebanon branch of the Nusra Front, a radical Syrian rebel force, claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing, saying it was part of a "series of vengeful attacks".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Feb-22/248183-suicide-bomber-kills-two-soldiers-in-e-Lebanon.ashx#axzz2u4YS3Zq7|title=Suicide bomber kills three in e. Lebanon|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Arsal bombing (March 29){{snd}}A suicide car bomb killed 3 Lebanese soldiers and wounded 4 others in the northeastern town of Arsal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Mar-29/251686-car-bomb-near-army-post-in-northeast-lebanon-sources.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Suicide bombing kills three soldiers in northeast Lebanon|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Dahr al Baidar bombing (June 20){{snd}}A suicide bomber killed a police officer and wounded 32 people at a checkpoint in east Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jun-20/260883-suicide-attack-hits-lebanese-police-checkpoint-in-dahr-al-baidar.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Suicide bomber kills police officer in east Lebanon|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Beirut cafe bombing (June 24){{snd}}A suicide bomber driving an old Mercedes wounded 12 people near a cafe and a military checkpoint in Beirut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jun-24/261334-midnight-suicide-bomber-jolts-beirut.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Midnight suicide bomber jolts Beirut|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Duroy Hotel bombing (June 27){{snd}}A suicide bomber wounded 11 people in a Beirut hotel. Security forces attempted to arrest him before the explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jun-25/261585-explosion-heard-in-beiruts-raouche.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Beirut bomber blows himself up to evade arrest|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Tripoli bomb (August 6){{snd}}A homemade bomb killed 1 civilian and wounded 10 others near an army checkpoint in Tripoli.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Aug-07/266339-tripoli-explosion-near-army-post-kills-civilian.ashx#axzz3ABS02nte|title=Tripoli explosion near Army post kills civilian|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *2nd Arsal bombing (September 19){{snd}}A bomb killed 2 Lebanese soldiers and wounded 3 others in Arsal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/border-rocket-attack-lebanon-army-wounds-2-military-100011178.html|title=Bomb attack kills 2 troops on Syria border: Lebanon army|date=19 September 2014|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Hezbollah bombing (September 20){{snd}}A bombing targeted a Hezbollah checkpoint in eastern Lebanon. The number of casualties is disputed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Sep-20/271378-suicide-bombing-near-hezbollah-checkpoint-in-east-lebanonsecurity-source.ashx#axzz3DrnM6eIf|title=Nusra Front claims attack on Hezbollah checkpoint|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *3rd Arsal bombing (November 14){{snd}}A bomb wounded 3 soldiers in Arsal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Nov-14/277609-bomb-wounds-two-lebanese-soldiers-in-arsal.ashx|title=Army ambushed after bomb wounds 3 soldiers in Arsal|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> *4th Arsal bombing (December 3){{snd}}Another bomb in Arsal killed 1 soldier and wounded 2 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Dec-03/279737-lebanese-army-expert-killed-as-he-dismantles-bomb.ashx|title=Lebanese Army expert killed as he examines bomb near Arsal|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
==2015==
*Jabal Mohsen cafe bombing (January 10){{snd}}A double suicide-bombing in Tripoli killed 9 people and injured at least 50 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2015/Jan-10/283682-explosions-heard-in-tripolis-jabal-mohsen-several-wounded-source.ashx|title=North Lebanon suicide attack kills nine|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> *Ghassan Ajaj assassination (January 26){{snd}}An intelligence officer was assassinated by a gunman in northern Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yalibnan.com/2015/01/27/isf-intelligence-officer-assassinated-in-zgharta-north-lebanon/|title=ISF Intelligence Officer assassinated in Zgharta, north Lebanon|author=yalibnan|publisher=|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> *Bader Eid assassination (March 2){{snd}}The brother of Alawite leader Ali Eid was assassinated in northern Lebanon.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2015/Mar-03/289380-brother-of-alawite</ref> *Second Hezbollah bombing (October 5){{snd}}A bombing targeted a bus transporting Hezbollah fighters to Syria. The number of casualties could not be determined.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/05/us-mideast-crisis-lebanon-blast-idUSKCN0RZ0WE20151005</ref> *5th Arsal bombing (November 5){{snd}}A bombing killed at least 5 people and wounded 15 others in the eastern town of Arsal.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/11/explosion-targets-muslim-committee-lebanon-arsal-151105120722733.html</ref> *6th Arsal bombing (November 6){{snd}}A blast wounded 5 Lebanese soldiers in Arsal.<ref>https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/NewsReports/566184-lebanon-army-hit-by-ied-in-arsal</ref> *Bourj el-Barajneh bombing (November 12){{snd}}Two suicide bombers killed at least 43 people and wounded more than 200 in the southern Beirut suburb of [[Bourj el-Barajneh]], a Hezbollah stronghold.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/beirut-bomb-scores-killed-in-twin-suicide-blast-in-lebanese-capital-a6732156.html</ref> *Deir Ammar bombing (December 5){{snd}}A suicide bomber killed 3 people and wounded 6 others during an army raid in North Lebanon.<ref>https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2015/Dec-05/326046-suicide-bomber-detonates-self-after-army-raids-his-home-in-north-lebanon-several-casualties-security.ashx</ref>
==2016==
*7th Arsal bombing (March 24){{snd}}A roadside bomb killed a Lebanese soldier and wounded 3 others in Arsal.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2016/Mar-24/343901-roadside-bomb-targets-army-convoy-in-northeast-lebanon-casualties-media-reports.ashx</ref> *Fathi Zaydan assassination (April 12){{snd}}An explosion killed Fathi Zaydan, a Fatah senior officer near the main Palestinian camp in South Lebanon.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2016/Apr-12/346948-car-bombing-targets-palestinian-official-near-ain-al-hilweh-camp-in-the-southern-city-of-sidon.ashx</ref> *Blom Bank bombing (June 12){{snd}}An explosion caused material damage outside a branch of the biggest bank in Lebanon.<ref>https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2016/Jun-12/356602-powerful-explosion-heard-in-beirut.ashx</ref> *Qaa Bombings (June 27){{snd}}Several suicide bombings killed at least 5 people and wounded more than 12 in the eastern village of Al Qaa.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/06/deadly-suicide-bombing-rocks-village-eastern-lebanon-160627032403154.html</ref> Security officials believe Islamic State militants were behind the attack although no one claimed responsibility. *8th Arsal bombing (August 15){{snd}}A bomb wounded 5 soldiers in the eastern village of Arsal.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2016/Aug-15/367244-roadside-bomb-explodes-at-army-post-near-arsal-entrance-casualties-reported-local-media.ashx</ref> *Zahle bombing (August 31){{snd}}A bomb killed 1 person and injured several others in the eastern city of Zahle.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2016/Aug-31/369808-roadside-bomb-explodes-in-east-lebanon-region-of-zahle-security-source.ashx</ref> *Al Ain (December 28){{snd}}A small explosion killed the deputy mayor of Al Ain, a town in northeastern Lebanon.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lebanon-blast-idUSKBN14H0CB</ref>
==2018==
*Mohammad Hamdan attempted assassination (January 14){{snd}}A car bomb injured a Hamas official in the southern city of Saida.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/01/car-bomb-blast-lebanon-sidon-wounds-hamas-member-180114154420846.html</ref>
==Pre-Lahoud term extension==
The assassinations and bombings listed above occurred after September 2004, in the aftermath of the forced term extension of the pro-Syrian Lebanese President [[Emile Lahoud]]. The events listed below had nothing to do with the extension of Emile Lahoud's presidential term, and most of them occurred long before.
*Riad al-Solh assassination (July 17, 1951){{snd}}Several months after leaving office [[Riad al-Solh]], Lebanon's first post-independence Prime Minister, was assassinated in Amman, Jordan by a member of the [[Syrian Social Nationalist Party]]. *Naim Moghabghab assassination (July 27, 1959){{snd}}MP [[Naim Moghabghab]] was assassinated in Maaser Beit el Dine, Lebanon after his car was attacked by opposition supporters. He is considered one of the heroes of the independence of Lebanon. *Maarouf Saad assassination (March 6, 1975){{snd}}The [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni]] politician and [[Sidon]] leader [[Maarouf Saad]] was shot on February 26 during a demonstration in [[Sidon]]. His death several days later was considered to be a partial trigger for the start of the civil war. *Kamal Jumblatt assassination (March 16, 1977){{snd}}[[Druze in Lebanon|Druze]] leader [[Kamal Jumblatt]] was killed close to his home in the [[Chouf]] area. Though it has not been proven in court, the assassination is largely blamed on Syria. *[[Ehden massacre]] (June 13, 1978){{snd}}[[Tony Franjieh]], son of former president [[Suleiman Franjieh]], was assassinated in his house by militiamen of the Lebanese [[Kataeb]] party. *Bashir Gemayel assassination (September 14, 1982){{snd}}President-elect [[Bashir Gemayel]] was killed by [[Habib Tanious Shartouni|Habib Shartouni]], a member of the [[Syrian Social Nationalist Party]]. His brother [[Amin Gemayel]] became president of Lebanon instead. *[[1983 United States Embassy bombing]] (April 18, 1983){{snd}}The American Embassy in Beirut was bombed. 63 people, including 17 Americans, lost their lives in the attack. *[[1983 Beirut barracks bombing]] (October 23, 1983){{snd}}The Beirut barracks bombing killed more than 200 American and French armed-forces personnel. *[[1985 Beirut car bombing]] (March 8, 1985){{snd}}More than 60 were killed and 200 injured in an explosion in Beirut.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/1985/mar/09/fromthearchive|title=60 killed by Beirut car bomb|work=the Guardian|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> *Rashid Karami assassination (June 1, 1987){{snd}}Prime Minister [[Rashid Karami]] was killed by bomb during a helicopter flight. *Hassan Khaled assassination (May 16, 1989){{snd}}Head of the Sunni community in Lebanon, [[Mufti]] [[Sheikh]] [[Hassan Khaled]], was killed by car bomb in Beirut. The assassination is largely blamed on Syria. *René Mouawad assassination (November 22, 1989){{snd}}President [[René Mouawad]], the second President of Lebanon to be killed by [[Syria]], was assassinated by a car bomb three weeks after becoming president. *Dany Chamoun assassination (October 21, 1990){{snd}}Leader of the National Liberal Party [[Dany Chamoun]] shot dead in a suburb of Beirut. *Abbas al-Musawi assassination (February 16, 1992){{snd}}Leader of [[Hezbollah]] [[Abbas al-Musawi]] was killed by [[Israel]] in Jibsheet, a town in [[southern Lebanon]]. *Elie Hobeika assassination (January 24, 2002){{snd}}Former [[Lebanese Forces]] intelligence officer, Syrian ally, former Lebanese government minister and member of parliament, and one of the planners of the [[Sabra and Shatila massacre]], [[Elie Hobeika]] was assassinated by a car bombing in the Beirut suburb of Hazmieh.
==See also== *[[Syrian occupation of Lebanon]] *[[Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon]] *[[Timeline of violent events relating to the Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon (2011–14)]] *[[Timeline of violent events relating to the Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon (2014–present)]]

revision.text:
A '''marriage bar''' is the custom and practice of restricting the [[employment]] of [[Marital status|married women]] in general or in particular [[profession]]s or occupations; sometimes the practice called for the termination of employment of a woman on her marriage, especially in teaching, clerical and other occupations, and sometimes widowed women with children were still considered to be married preventing them from being hired.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = "Must a woman . . . give it all up when she marries?": The Debate over Employing Married Women as Teachers|url = http://montanawomenshistory.org/must-a-woman-give-it-all-up-when-she-marries-the-debate-over-employing-married-women-as-teachers/|website = Women's History Matters|accessdate = 2015-11-04|language = en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|jstor=23196053|title=JSTOR}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bitesize/standard/history/scotland_britain_1880_now/employment_women/revision/3/|title=BBC - Standard Grade Bitesize History - Women and work : Revision, Page 3|work=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref>
The practice never had an economic justification, and its rigid application could be disruptive to workplaces. It was justified during depression years as a social policy to find jobs for more family units, but the policy persisted beyond such economic times. The practice was common in some Western countries from the late 19th century to the 1970s. Marriage bars created a disincentive for women to marry, at least until they were ready to give up work, and some women, including [[Ruby Payne-Scott]], kept their marriage secret to keep their jobs. Marriage bars did not affect employment in lower paid jobs, and therefore lowered incentives for women to acquire [[education]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor Economics|first=George J.|last=Borjas|edition=4th|year=2007|page=402|location=London|publisher=McGraw-Hill|isbn=978-0073402826}}</ref> Marriage bars were widely relaxed in wartime.
Since the 1960s, the practice has widely been regarded as [[employment discrimination|employment inequality]] and [[Discrimination#Sex.2C gender.2C and gender identity|sexual discrimination]], and has widely been either discontinued or outlawed by [[anti-discrimination law]]s which may also deal with discrimination based on [[marital status]]. In the [[Netherlands]], the marriage bar was removed in 1957,<ref>''The Economics of Imperfect Labor Markets: Second Edition'', by Tito Boeri, Jan van Ours, pp. 105</ref><ref>[https://rm.coe.int/CoERMPublicCommonSearchServices/DisplayDCTMContent?documentId=090000168045ae0e Dutch gender and LGBT-equality policy, 2013-16]</ref><ref>[http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/Gender/publication/Netherlands_2015_Review_BPFA_Report_of_the_Netherlands_Government.pdf 2015 Review BPFA Report of the Netherlands Government]</ref> and in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] it was instituted in 1932 and removed in 1973.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/sites/martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/files/Patterson.pdf |title=Women of Ireland: Change Toward Social and Political Equality in the 21st Century Irish Republic |first=Rachel A. |last=Patterson |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151008154655/https://martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/sites/martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/files/Patterson.pdf |archivedate=October 8, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Galligan|title="Women and National Identity in the Republic of Ireland".|date=1997|pages=45–53}}</ref> Since 1975, female officers of the [[British Geological Survey]] no longer have to resign upon getting married.<ref name="British">{{cite web|author=Rod Bowie, Records Centre Manager, National Geological Records Centre, British Geological Survey, Keyworth|url=file:///C:/Users/Pjohnson/Downloads/Freedom%20and%20Equalit2_fin%20(1).pdf|title=Freedom and Equality-Women in Geology|language=English |publisher=British Geological Survey, [[Natural Environment Research Council]] |date= |accessdate=2018-05-23}}</ref>
==Types== Generally, marriage bars can be classified as the “hire bar” preventing the hiring of married women, and the “retain bar” preventing the retention of married workers.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal |title=Marriage Bars: Discrimination Against Married Women Workers, 1920's to 1950's |work=NBER Working Paper No. 2747 |date=October 1988 |first=Claudia |last=Goldin |doi=10.3386/w2747 }}</ref>
Marriage bars also meant that often female employees were classified as supplementary staff, rather than permanent. This was the case, for example, at [[Lloyds Bank]] until 1949, when the bank abolished its marriage bar.<ref>http://www.lloydsbankinggroup.com/our-group/our-heritage/timeline/1901-1950/</ref>
== Reasons given for marriage bars == A 1946 article in ''[[The Spectator]]'', a British conservative magazine, gave (and dismissed) a few reasons for the implementation of the marriage bars.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = The Marriage Bar » 22 Aug 1946 » The Spectator Archive|url = http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/23rd-august-1946/2/the-marriage-bar|website = The Spectator Archive|accessdate = 2015-11-04}}</ref> Arguments included: women who were married were supported by their husbands, therefore they did not need jobs.<ref name=":0" /> Marriage bars provided more opportunity for those whom proponents viewed as "actually" needing employment, such as single women.<ref name=":0" /> Another argument ''The Spectator'' makes states unmarried women are more reliable and mobile than married women.<ref name=":0" /> As single women did not have a family or other pressing responsibilities, they were more reliable and flexible than married women.<ref name=":0" /> The last point made by this magazine involves the turnover rate.<ref name=":0" /> The turnover rate for women in these jobs was high because lots of young single women eventually got married.<ref name=":0" /> Since they did not hold their positions very long, it gave them less of an opportunity for advancement and promotions.<ref name=":0" />
Marriage bars were connected to social and economic fluctuations, for example, after the end of [[World War I]], returning servicemen who wanted jobs, and afterwards the depression in the 1930s, led to the implementation of marriage bars in many professions during the [[interbellum period]].<ref>http://www.striking-women.org/module/women-and-work/inter-war-years-1918-1939</ref> However, marriage bars were often justified on moral grounds, especially in places where there was a very strong tradition of married women staying at home and being [[housewives]], something more common in rich countries, such as, for instance, the [[Netherlands]].<ref>http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/Gender/publication/Netherlands_2015_Review_BPFA_Report_of_the_Netherlands_Government.pdf</ref>
== Exceptions to marriage bars == ''Women's History Matters'' states that marriage bars had some exceptions.<ref name=":1" /> Contrary to urban areas, rural areas needed teachers so they were willing to hire married women.<ref name=":1" /> Schools were also willing to hire women if they could prove that their husbands were “invalid, insane, or unable to provide for the family".<ref name=":1" /> Marriage bars were less strict during World War II, because the women were needed again for these jobs.<ref name=":1" /> For example, in Montana, 1500 women were welcomed back into the school systems for the duration of World War II only.<ref name=":1" /> Around the time of WW ll 87% of school boards would not hire married women and 70% would not retain a single woman who married. But later on in 1951 18% of the school boards had the "hire bar" and 10% had the "retain bar".<ref name=":2" /> Marriage bars only applied to educated, middle-class married women, particularly native born white women. Their occupations were that of teaching, and clerical work. These occupations were most needed and required in secondary school education. Meanwhile, lower class women of colour who took jobs in manufacturing, waitressing, and domestic servants were unaffected by marriage bans.<ref name=":2" /> Discrimination against married female teachers in the US was not terminated until 1964 with the passing of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|Civil Rights Act]].<ref name=":1" />
The [[BBC]] had a marriage bar between 1932 and 1944, although it was a partial ban and was not fully enforced due to the BBC's ambivalent views on the policy.<ref>http://tcbh.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/02/23/tcbh.hwu002.abstract</ref>
==References== <references />
==Further information== * [http://www.apsc.gov.au/media/briggs201106.htm Celebration of the 40th anniversary of the lifting of the Marriage Bar] - transcript of a speech by [[Lynelle Briggs]] in 2006, regarding the marriage bar in the [[Australian Public Service]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Marriage Bars}} [[Category:Women's rights]] [[Category:Feminist economics]] [[Category:Employment discrimination]] [[Category:Sexism]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Negotiated order''' is an approach in [[sociology]] that is interested in how meaning is created and maintained in organizations. It has a particular focus on human interactions.

'''Peace economics''' is a specialized branch of [[economics]]. Peace economics focuses on the design of the sociosphere's political, economic, and cultural institutions and their interacting policies and actions with the goal of preventing, mitigating, or resolving violent conflict within and between societies. This violent conflict could be of any type and could involve either latent or actual violence.<ref>Brauer, Jurgen and Raul Caruso. (2012). "Economists and Peacebuilding." In Roger MacGintry (ed.), Handbook on Peacebuilding. London: Routledge.</ref> Presuming knowledge of the cost of violence, it focuses on the benefits of (re)constructing societies<ref>Keynes, John M. (1920). The Economic Consequences of the Peace. London: Macmillan.</ref><ref>Boulding, Kenneth E. (1945). The Economics of Peace. New York: Prentice-Hall.</ref><ref>Del Castillo, Graciana. (2008). Rebuilding War-Torn States: The Challenge of Post-Conflict Economic Reconstruction. New York: Oxford University Press.</ref><ref>Brauer, Jurgen and J. Paul Dunne. (2012). Peace Economics: A Macroeconomic Primer for Violence-Afflicted States. Washington, D.C.: United States Institute of Peace Press.</ref> with a view toward achieving irreversible, stable [[peace]].<ref>Boulding, Kenneth E. (1978). Stable Peace. Austin, TX: The University of Texas Press.</ref> Together with approaches drawn from disciplines such as anthropology, sociology, psychology and cognitive science, geography and regional science, and political science and international relations, peace economics forms part of peace science, an evolving part of [[peace and conflict studies]].<ref>Isard, Walter. (1992). Understanding Conflict and the Science of Peace. Cambridge, MA: Blackwell.</ref>
Peace economics is distinct from both war economics and military economics, even though there may be substantial overlap between these disciplines.<ref>Poast, Paul. (2006). The Economics of War. New York: McGraw-Hill Irwin.</ref><ref>Hartley, Keith and Todd Sandler, eds. (1995). Handbook of Defense Economics. Vol. 1. Amsterdam: Elsevier.</ref><ref>Sandler, Todd and Keith Hartley. (1995). The Economics of Defense. New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref><ref>Smith, Ron P. (2009). Military Economics: The Interaction of Power and Money. New York: Palgrave Macmillan.</ref> Peace economics is also distinct from [[conflict economics]],<ref>Hirshleifer, Jack. (2001). The Dark Side of the Force: Economic Foundations of Conflict Theory. Cambridge, MA: Cambridge University Press.</ref><ref>Anderton, Charles H. and John R. Carter. (2009). Principles of Conflict Economics: A Primer for Social Scientists. New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref> and it is distinct from security economics.<ref>Brück, Tilman. (2005). "An Economic Analysis of Security Policies." Defense and Peace Economics. Vol. 16, No. 5, pp. 375-389.</ref> A key difference between peace economics and these related fields is that peace economics emphasizes a study of the presence of peace, as distinct from studying the absence or presence of conflict, violence, war, or insecurity.
==Other definitions==
Peace economics has also been defined as "the use of economics to understand the causes and effects of violent conflict in the international system and the ways that conflict can be avoided, managed, or resolved."<ref>Anderton, Charles H. and John R. Carter. (2007). "A Survey of Peace Economics," pp. 1211-1258 in Todd Sandler and Keith Hartley, eds., Handbook of Defense Economics. Vol. 2. Amsterdam: Elsevier. The quote is from p. 1212.</ref> This restricts the subject matter to the international realm and leaves out the study of peace itself. [[Walter Isard]] defines peace economics as "generally concerned with: (1) resolution, management or reduction of conflict in the economic sphere, or among behaving units in their economic activity; (2) the use of economic measures and policy to cope with and control conflicts whether economic or not; and (3) the impact of conflict on the economic behavior and welfare of firms, consumers organizations, government and society."<ref>Isard, Walter. (1994). "Peace Economics: A Topical Perspective." Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy. Vol. 1, No. 2, pp. 11-13. The quote is from p. 11. [A slightly revised reprint of Walter Isard, "Peace Economics" in Douglas Greenwald, Editor in Chief, The McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Economics. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1994, pp. 767-769.]</ref> The notion of violence is absent and peace itself is not studied, but the level of analysis can be other than conflict between states. In a context restricted to international trade, another author writes that "Peace economics studies ways to eradicate and control conflict as well as to assess conflict's impact on society."<ref>Polachek, Solomon W. (1994). "Peace Economics: A Trade Theory Perspective." Peace Economics, Peace Science and Public Policy. Vol. 1, No. 2, pp.14-17. The quote is from p. 14.</ref> The notion of violence is not explicit and the benefits of peace are seen only inasmuch as a reduction of conflict may improve opportunities for expanded global trade. Others make a distinction between "productive" and "unproductive" or "appropriative" economic activities their starting point of analysis in peace economics.<ref>Haavelmo, Trygve. (1954). A Study in the Theory of Economic Evolution. Amsterdam: North-Holland.</ref><ref>Dumas, Lloyd J. (1986). The Overburdened Economy: Uncovering the Causes of Chronic Unemployment, Inflation, and National Decline. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press.</ref><ref>Baumol, William J. (1990). "Entrepreneurship: Productive, Unproductive, and Destructive." The Journal of Political Economy. Vol. 98, No. 5, Part 1 (October), pp. 893-921.</ref><ref name="CarusoRaul">Caruso, Raul. (2010). "On the Nature of Peace Economics." Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy. Vol. 16, No. 2, Article 2.</ref>
Economics Nobelist [[Jan Tinbergen]] defines peace economics as "economic science used for [a purpose that] prohibits [war] as an instrument of settling conflicts between nations and [to organize] the world in a way that warfare is punished".<ref>Tinbergen Jan. (1994). "What is Peace Economics?" Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy. Vol. 1, No. 4, pp. 3-5. The quote is from p. 3.</ref> Violence is addressed only at the level of sovereigns, not dealing with civil war or debilitating organized or individual-level criminal violence. In related work, Tinbergen writes about a [[International relations|world order]] that would inhibit violence and permit peace between and among states. In his view, this requires a "world government",<ref>Tinbergen Jan. (1994). "What is Peace Economics?" Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy. Vol. 1, No. 4, pp. 3-5. The quote is from p. 3 as well.</ref><ref>Also see Tinbergen, Jan and Dietrich Fischer (1987). Warfare and Welfare: Integrating Security Policy into Socio-Economic Policy. New York: St. Martin's Press, and Tinbergen Jan. (1990). World Security and Equity. Aldershot, UK: Elgar.</ref> a sentiment not now commonly agreed among economists. These definitions of peace economics all share [[Johan Galtung]]'s characterization of negative peace (the absence of violent conflict) as opposed to positive peace (the presence of peace-enabling structures).
==Methods, norms, and context==
A number of peace economists are explicit about the use of particular explanatory schema to be applied in peace economics, e.g., [[rational choice theory]].<ref>Dacey, Ray. (1994). "Peace Economics as the Political Economy of Peace and War." Peace Economics, Peace Science and Public Policy. Vol. 2, No. 1, pp.8-12.</ref> In contrast, the main definition of peace economics is open to a variety of approaches. Virtually all authors acknowledge that peace economics is part of both [[positive economics]] and [[normative economics]].<ref name="CarusoRaul" /><ref>Arrow, Kenneth J. (1995). "Some General Observations on the Economics of Peace and War, Peace Economics." Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy. Vol. 2, No. 2, pp. 1-8.</ref> While for most contemporary economists, work in positive economics may lead them to lay out a descriptive array or evaluation of [[policy]] choices from which one that is most valued is recommended to or chosen by policy makers, in peace economics, in contrast, it is the norm of peace to be achieved that inspires the search for a system design that can reliably deliver on the desired norm.
Peace economics is built on [[general systems theory]] exemplified by the work of [[Kenneth Boulding]].<ref>Boulding, Kenneth E. (1970). "Economics as a Social Science," pp. 1-22 and "Economics as a Political Science," pp. 77-96, both in Kenneth E. Boulding, Economics as a Science. New York: McGraw-Hill.</ref> Earth may be viewed as a self-regulating ([[homeostatic]]) system, consisting of natural and social subsystems. In each, deviation from a set goal is self-corrected through feedback loops. Homeostatic systems are commonly observed in nature, such as in ecology and in the physiology of organisms (e.g., self-regulation of population sizes, self-regulation of body heat). The systems concept has been adopted in the engineering sciences, for example in designing thermostats. The user sets a desired goal state (temperature), the instrument measures the actual state, and for a deviation of sufficient degree a corrective action is taken (heating or cooling).
Relatively new is the insight that social systems designed to achieve certain purposes (e.g., the retirement or pension system) imply a [[choice architecture]] that may permit failed or failing social systems to persist. Similarly, choice architecture may facilitate the (re)design of institutions aimed at securing beneficial social outcomes such as peace. This is [[social engineering (political science)|social engineering]] applied to the problem of peace (peace engineering)<ref>Fischer, Dietrich. (1993). Nonmilitary Aspects of Security: A Systems Approach. Brookfield, VT: Dartmouth Publ.</ref> and overlaps with ideas of [[mechanism design]] (reverse game theory) in which a solution is stipulated a priori and the structure of the game that would bring about the desired outcome is inferred. In this way, system design links back to normative economics.
==Examples==
===Free trade and peace=== [[File:Economic connections between US, EU, China, Russia and India.png|thumb|Economic ties between the US, EU, China, Russia and India (thickness of the lines is proportional to the bilateral trade volume)]] The classical English liberals of the 19th century largely believed that [[free trade]] promoted peace. This view, attributed to [[Adam Smith]] and [[Edmund Burke]], was evident in the advocacy of [[Richard Cobden]] and [[John Bright]], and in the writings of the most prominent English economists and political thinkers of the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as [[John Stuart Mill]] and [[Alfred Marshall]]. [[John Maynard Keynes]] said that he was "brought up" on this idea.<ref>[[Donald Markwell]], ''John Maynard Keynes and International Relations: Economic Paths to War and Peace'', Oxford University Press, 2006, chapter 2.</ref> A prominent 20th century US exponent of this idea was the Secretary of State under President [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]], [[Cordell Hull]].
===World War I and the Paris Peace Conference===
Upon resigning from the United Kingdom's Treasury team at the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]] in June 1919, [[John Maynard Keynes]] penned a small book. Published in 1920, ''The Economic Consequences of the Peace'' famously lays out his case for why the allies' Terms of Peace to be imposed on Germany were physically and financially impossible to fulfill and how they would encourage Germany to rise up again. Predicting a coming World War II, Keynes wrote: "... if this view of nations and of their relation to one another (i.e., a [[Carthaginian peace|Carthaginian Peace]]) is adopted by the democracies of Western Europe, and is financed by the United States, heaven help us all. If we aim deliberately at the impoverishment of Central Europe, vengeance, I dare predict, will not limp. Nothing can then delay for very long that final civil war between the forces of Reaction and the despairing convulsions of Revolution, before which the horrors of the late German war will fade into nothing, and which will destroy, whoever is victor, the civilisation and the progress of our generation."<ref>Keynes, John M. (1920). The Economic Consequences of the Peace. London: Macmillan. The quote is from p. 251.</ref> Although Keynes' effort to change the treaty terms failed, it is a dramatic demonstration of what peace economics is about: the creation of a mutually reinforcing structure of political, economic, and cultural systems to achieve peace such that reversal to violence is unlikely.
===Capitalism and war, and managed capitalism=== In the 1930s, in the midst of the [[Great Depression]] and with the rise of fascist powers, many western socialist and liberal thinkers believed that capitalism caused war. However, Keynes in his ''General Theory of Enployment, Interest and Money'' in 1936, argued that this need not be so, and that the management of capitalism along the lines he proposed to promote high employment would be more conducive to peace than [[laissez-faire]] capitalism with the [[gold standard]] had been. This analysis underlay his approach during World War II to the creation of institutions for international economic governance in the post-war world.<ref>[[Donald Markwell]], ''John Maynard Keynes and International Relations: Economic Paths to War and Peace'', Oxford University Press, 2006, chapters 5 & 6.</ref>
===World War II, Bretton Woods, and the Marshall Plan===
Late in World War II, as Nazi-Germany's eventual defeat appeared clear, [[Henry Morgenthau, Jr.]], then-Secretary of the United States Treasury, advocated the partitioning of Germany, stripping it of its most valuable raw materials and industrial assets, and envisioned the complete pastoralization of Germany. [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and [[Winston Churchill]] agreed to the [[Morgenthau Plan]], in modified form, on 16 September 1944. Following victory, Germany's remaining factories were dismantled, parts, machinery, and equipment shipped abroad, patents expropriated, research forbidden, and useful engineers and scientists transferred out of the country. Despite the negotiation of international treaties at [[United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference|Bretton Woods]] to create a set of complementary global monetary, trade, and reconstruction and development institutions, namely the [[International Monetary Fund]], the [[International Bank for Reconstruction and Development]] (today part of the [[World Bank Group]]), and, separately, the [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (incorporated in today's [[World Trade Organization]]), Germany's and Europe's other postwar economies collapsed. Keynes' Economic Consequences of the Peace appeared to repeat themselves. However, Roosevelt had died and [[Harry S. Truman]] assumed the U.S. American Presidency on 12 April 1945. Even as the deindustrialization of Germany proceeded as planned, Truman's first Secretary of State, [[James F. Byrnes]], by 1947 took a dismal view of its effects on Germany's impoverished population. So did former president [[Herbert C. Hoover]] in a series of reports penned in 1947. Meanwhile, [[Joseph Stalin]]'s Soviet Union emerged as a formidable power and the implication seemed clear: An economically strengthened, resurgent Germany could either be part of a new Western political, economic, and cultural alliance or else be incorporated into a Soviet one. Truman thus came to abolish the punitive measures imposed on Germany, and his new Secretary of State, General [[George C. Marshall]], formulated what would become the [[Marshall Plan]], in effect from 1948 to 1952. The new global institutions and the unilateral Marshall Plan action combined to endow new institutions with sufficient resources to result in a somewhat unwitting peace economics: clearly designed toward the purpose of international peace and prosperity, yet skewed toward Western Europe and the incipient [[Cold War]]. Moreover, the new social architecture was invested with incentives, such as the [[United Nations Security Council]] that provided five of its members with permanent seats and veto powers, that, while keeping superpower peace, threatened peace and prosperity in the post-colonial [[Third World]].
===Origins of the European Union===
Like Keynes, [[Jean Monnet]] participated in the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, in Monnet's case as an assistant to the French delegation. Like Keynes, he envisioned a pan-European economic cooperation zone. Like Keynes, he would be disappointed. Despite this, the French appreciated his good efforts and awarded him with the post of Deputy Secretary-General of the then newly founded [[League of Nations]]. Monnet was but 31 years old. He resigned four years later to devote himself to international business and finance in private capacity but resurfaced during the early World War II years in positions of high influence in France, Britain, and the United States, urging Roosevelt to get on with an industrial armaments plan. Following World War II, Monnet, however, at first crafted the [[Monnet Plan]] which, similar to Morgenthau's, envisioned the transfer of the German [[Ruhr]] and [[Saarland]] territories, raw materials, and industries (coal and steel) to France to assist it in its own reconstruction. This was approved by French Prime Minister [[Charles de Gaulle]] shortly before his resignation in January 1946. The transfer of the Saar region took place with U.S. help in 1947, while the Ruhr region was placed under an international authority in 1949 that assured France access to German coal at low prices. This led to rising frictions between Germany and the allies, just as Keynes had foretold 30 years earlier.
Monnet changed course and, together with Paul Reuter, Bernard Clappier, Pierre Uri, and Étienne Hirsch, plans were crafted that resulted in the [[Schuman Declaration]] of 9 May 1950, celebrated today as [[Europe Day]] or Schuman Day. [[Robert Schuman]], the Franco-German-Luxembourgian statesman, French Minister of Finance, Minister of Foreign Affairs and two-time Prime Minister of France, envisioned, first, a Franco-German and, then, a pan-European sharing of crucial coal and steel resources among Italy, France, Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg that would make future war "not only unthinkable but materially impossible."<ref>"Declaration of 9 May 1950." http://www.robert-schuman.eu/declaration_9mai.php. (Retrieved on 14 February 2012.)</ref> By 1951, this resulted in the formation of the [[European Coal and Steel Community]] (ECSC), the forerunner to today's [[European Union]]. In contrast to the negotiations surrounding the founding of the [[United Nations]] and a set of associated organizations in 1945, the European idea appears to have been deliberately designed as a kernel with organic growth-potential, the precise development of which would be learned in future. Thus, no institutional structures were put in place that, due to accrued vested interests, would later prove to be too difficult to change.
===Current research directions===
War at the interstate level has subsided and, to a degree, so have the massive civil wars that took place in the immediate Post-Cold War period (especially in Africa in the 1990s and 2000s).<ref>Human Security Report 2009/2010. Human Security Report Project. http://www.hsrgroup.org/human-security-reports/20092010/overview.aspx (Retrieved 14 February 2012.) For longer-term trends, see Steven Pinker, ''The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence has Declined '' (New York: Viking, 2011) and literature cited therein.</ref> But violent conflict takes place at many levels, from self-directed harm (e.g., self-injury and [[suicide]]) and [[domestic violence]] between intimate partners and family members to [[workplace violence]] and [[Organized crime|organized criminal violence]], all of which are massively costly and ultimately require positive, structural solutions whereby resort to violence becomes "unthinkable," even as it may remain "materially possible."
The [[Institute for Economics and Peace]], a think tank with offices in Sydney, New York, and Mexico City, is "developing metrics to analyse peace and to quantify its economic value. It does this by developing global and national indices, calculating the economic cost of violence, analysing country level risk and understanding positive peace." <ref>http://economicsandpeace.org/</ref>
==Journals== Academic journals that publish work by peace economists include the ''Journal of Conflict Resolution'' (since 1956), the ''Journal of Peace Research'' (since 1964), ''Conflict Management and Peace Science'' (since 1973), ''Defence and Peace Economics'' (since 1990), ''Peace Economics, Peace Science, and Public Policy'' (since 1993), the ''Economics of Peace and Security Journal'' (since 2006), the ''International Journal of Development and Conflict'' (since 2011), and ''Business, Peace and Sustainable Development'' (since 2013).
==Key figures== * [[Kenneth Boulding]] * [[Jurgen Brauer]] * [[Trygve Haavelmo]] * [[Michael Intriligator]] * [[Walter Isard]] * [[John Maynard Keynes]] * [[Jan Tinbergen]]
